line.comment: * Task 0
* MordanB - Even at half laser range, the small "hit box" of fighters makes the repair laser miss often.
* This only manifests when the player is in-system, but regardless, if the target is tiny, we're going to move closer in order to
* eliminate most of the "hit box" problem. A repair laser is still a laser and the game treats it like it can miss.
* and the target still exists
* write to logfile 1 append=[TRUE] printf: fmt='Target doesnt exist', null, null, null, null, null
* keep moving until we get in the same sector as the target.
* double check that the target is still not moving. Bail completely if it is.
* Check to make sure the target didn't dock or leave.
* write to logfile 1 append=[TRUE] printf: fmt='Spot 1', null, null, null, null, null
* Move within range.
* We weren't close enough, and yet the move command didn't bring us any closer. We've come to a stop too far away. In this case, reduce the Followdistance by a bit.
* safety check, in case we can't seem to ever move close enough. Allow 3 reductions in distance.

line.text: 'Failed to move within repair range after 3 tries.'

line.comment: * write to log file 1 append=[TRUE] printf: fmt='Within Range of Target. Distance=%s, laserRange=%s', $Distance, $laserRange, null, null, null
* We're within range if we get here.
* Limitation of the game: the "in firing range of" command NeVER works right, in system or out of system. Don't use it.
* if [THIS]-> is $ship in firing range of turret 0 BROKEN command. Does not work in or out of system correctly.
* Issue the follow command first, which essentially TURNS the ship towards the target, allowing the primary lasers to hit. Otherwise it fires into space.

line.text: 'In-System: Ship not in firing range, but Distance %s < Firing Range of turret 0.'

line.comment: * OOS
* OOS can't use the "in firing range of" command, as this appears broken.
* Additionally, repair lasers fired OOS just seems to destroy the target ship, even when it's not supposed to. Apparently no one ever
* intended to use repair lasers like this. So.. We'll fudge it.
* don't care much about this value.. Just make sure we're in the neighborhood of the ship. We're OOS so not important that we're right on top of the target.

line.text: 'OOS: Ship not in firing range, but Distance %s < laserRange %s.'

line.comment: * if repair is done
* write to log file 1 append=[TRUE] printf: fmt='Finished Repairs', null, null, null, null, null
* end while 1
* Herobetty 5.4: fix for abandoned ships and if ships switch allegiances.

line.text: '---- Repairs Terminated. The target ship is no longer in Standby. ----'
'---- Repairs Terminated. The target ship is no longer abandoned or under your control. ----'
'Repair Target not found at destination. Repairs Cancelled.'

line.comment: * Repair lasers OOS tend to destroy target ships. Fun fun. So if OOS, we just keep it simple and add hull to the target every x seconds.
* not one can see it, so no one will care.
* This rate mirrors the general observed in-system repair rate. That's about 1500 hull / second repair. We'll do a bit better OOS because I like it that way.

sval.val: Moving to %s
Repairing %s
Moving to Target. Distance=%s, Followdistance=%s
Failed to move within repair range after 3 tries.
In-System: Ship not in firing range, but Distance %s < Firing Range of turret 0.
OOS: Ship not in firing range, but Distance %s < laserRange %s.
Finished Repairs on
---- Repairs Terminated. The target ship is no longer in Standby. ----
---- Repairs Terminated. The target ship is no longer abandoned or under your control. ----
Repair Target not found at destination. Repairs Cancelled.
Task 0
MordanB - Even at half laser range, the small "hit box" of fighters makes the repair laser miss often.
This only manifests when the player is in-system, but regardless, if the target is tiny, we're going to move closer in order to
eliminate most of the "hit box" problem. A repair laser is still a laser and the game treats it like it can miss.
and the target still exists
write to logfile 1 append=[TRUE] printf: fmt='Target doesnt exist', null, null, null, null, null
keep moving until we get in the same sector as the target.
double check that the target is still not moving. Bail completely if it is.
Check to make sure the target didn't dock or leave.
write to logfile 1 append=[TRUE] printf: fmt='Spot 1', null, null, null, null, null
Move within range.
We weren't close enough, and yet the move command didn't bring us any closer. We've come to a stop too far away. In this case, reduce the Followdistance by a bit.
safety check, in case we can't seem to ever move close enough. Allow 3 reductions in distance.
write to log file 1 append=[TRUE] printf: fmt='Within Range of Target. Distance=%s, laserRange=%s', $Distance, $laserRange, null, null, null
We're within range if we get here.
Limitation of the game: the "in firing range of" command NeVER works right, in system or out of system. Don't use it.
if [THIS]-> is $ship in firing range of turret 0 BROKEN command. Does not work in or out of system correctly.
Issue the follow command first, which essentially TURNS the ship towards the target, allowing the primary lasers to hit. Otherwise it fires into space.
OOS can't use the "in firing range of" command, as this appears broken.
Additionally, repair lasers fired OOS just seems to destroy the target ship, even when it's not supposed to. Apparently no one ever
intended to use repair lasers like this. So.. We'll fudge it.
don't care much about this value.. Just make sure we're in the neighborhood of the ship. We're OOS so not important that we're right on top of the target.
if repair is done
write to log file 1 append=[TRUE] printf: fmt='Finished Repairs', null, null, null, null, null
end while 1
Herobetty 5.4: fix for abandoned ships and if ships switch allegiances.
Repair lasers OOS tend to destroy target ships. Fun fun. So if OOS, we just keep it simple and add hull to the target every x seconds.
not one can see it, so no one will care.
This rate mirrors the general observed in-system repair rate. That's about 1500 hull / second repair. We'll do a bit better OOS because I like it that way.
